Award.AbstractNarration:
The mathematical study of 3-dimensional spaces goes back to the work of Poincar(e. Because classical physics describes our universe to be a 3-dimensional space, the classification of 3-dimensional spaces is an important mathematical endeavor, since it may have ramifications for the global structure of our universe. One of the most broad and interesting classes of 3-dimensional spaces are "hyperbolic manifolds", which are described by discrete groups of two by two complex matrices. These groups can have manifestations as higher-dimensional matrices, which the PI plans to explore. The importance for the study of 3-dimensional spaces may stem from the study of "bundles" over the spaces, which attach vector data to each point in the 3-dimensional space. The PI plans to investigate the moduli of such bundles, both in terms of dimension, and number of components (which structures can be deformed to each other). The project plans to take advantage of recent advances in the understanding of 3-dimensional hyperbolic spaces discovered by the PI and others. There may be ramifications for the algorithmic classification of 3-dimensional spaces and their invariants.


This project proposes several avenues of study regarding representations of 3-manifold groups. The PI will investigate the profinite completions of hyperbolic 3-manifold groups. In particular, the PI will explore which information about a 3-manifold may be extracted from the finite quotients of its fundamental group, including hyperbolic volume and rank. The PI proposes to investigate the dimension of the space of faithful irreducible representations as the dimension of the representations increases. The PI plans to use right-angled Artin groups and embeddings of 3-manifolds into them to investigate this question. A related question is to investigate the growth of the number of volumes of n-dimensional representations of hyperbolic 3-manifold groups as n increases. Finally, the PI will investigate twisted-homology of hyperbolic taut sutured 3-manifolds. In particular, the PI would like to find criteria for when they are twisted SL(2,C)-homology products, motivated by the problem of determining when twisted SL(2,C) Alexander polynomials detect the Seifert genus (or more generally Thurston norm).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported research in 3-dimensional topology and geometry. 

Topology studies properties of spaces which are invariant under deformations. Three dimenisonal spaces may be described locally by three variables, but globally can curve back on themselves creating non-trivial topology. The geometrization theorem implies that many of these spaces admit a canonical global distance function which is "hyperbolic", or saddle shaped. This grant supported research into the topological invariants of these spaces, especially the hyperbolic ones. Other topics considered were graphs embedded in 3-manifolds.  

 

The Seifert genus of a knot is one of the clasical invariants of knots. With Nathan Dunfield, we showed that the twisted Alexander polynomial (an invariant associated to the hyperbolic metric)  detects the genus of certain classes of knots. This confirmed a conjecture of Dunfield-Friedl-Jackson in many cases. 

 

Franco Vargas investigated the renormalized volume of hyperbolic manifolds. This invariant was introduced by physicists studying Einstein manifolds with a particular conformal structure at infinity. In the 3-dimenisonal Riemannian case, one gets a number associated to hyperbolic 3-manifolds. Vargas showed that this volume is minimized for hyperbolic manifolds with a fixed topology by the metric with geodesic boundary (if it exists), and more generally that it is non-negative when the manifold has incompressible boundary. 

 

Alvin Kerber investigated which Kleinian groups contain closed surface subgroups without parabolics. For certain hyperbolic manifolds whose underlying topological space is a book of I-bundles, he determined which ones have such a surface. 

 

With Slava Krushkal, we investigated the flow polynomial of cubic graphs and the Yamada polynomial of spatial cubic graphs. We formulated a conjecture that Tutte's golden identity for flow polynomials of cubic planar graphs extends to a strict inequality for non-planar cubic graphs. We proved this for certain families of non-planar cubic graphs. We also showed that the golden identity extends to an identity for the Yamada polynomial of spatial graphs. This implied a curious quadratic congruence satisfied by the flow polynomials of cubic graphs. We also showed that the flow polynomials of cubic planar graphs grow exponentially, answering a question of Treumann and Zaslow.
